title: The most popular fact checks of October
subtitle: Our monthly round-up of our most popular fact checks was topped by a statement on guns by President Obama.
author: www.washingtonpost.com
vclaim:
1: Obama’s claim that ‘states with the most gun laws tend to have the fewest gun deaths’

President Obama claimed that the states with the most gun laws tend to have the fewest gun deaths, but this was a classic situation in which a politician bases a statement on a study, but then exaggerated the conclusions to justify a policy. We demonstrated how the state rankings changed dramatically when suicides are removed from the gun deaths—and the evidence is mixed on whether restricting gun purchases would affect the overall suicide rate. In any case, the president’s policy proposals are aimed at mass shootings, not suicides. He earned Two Pinocchios.

2: Clinton’s claim that 40 percent of guns are sold at gun shows and over the Internet

Former secretary of state Hillary Rodham Clinton cited a stale statistic—and then got it wrong, claiming that “forty percent of guns are sold at gun shows, online sales.” The 40-percent figure refers to all gun transactions, not just gun sales. A large percentage of the gun transactions not covered by background checks are family and friend transactions – which would have been exempt from the universal background checks pushed by Democrats. Clinton earned Three Pinocchios.

3: Cruz’s claim that he spent ‘much of my adult life in law enforcement’

Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Tex.) claimed that he “spent much of my adult life working in law enforcement.” But we found he was exaggerating his law-enforcement credentials. To say that “much” of his adult life was spent in law enforcement really suggests at least half of his career, whereas the best-case scenario would be one-third. Even then, he was never a prosecutor or litigated criminal cases — and in private practice, he defended criminals. He earned Three Pinocchios.

Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) made a bold claim at one of the GOP debates, so we did a deep dive into the evidence concerning Clinton’s public and private statements on the 2012 Benghazi attacks. A “lie” suggests a deliberate effort to deceive, but we found the documentary evidence suggests there were few hard answers available then to policymakers. Rubio earned Two Pinocchios.

5: Elizabeth Warren’s claim that the bottom 90 percent got ‘zero percent’ of wage growth after Reagan

We examined the evidence for Sen. Warren’s frequent assertion about income inequality, often made in a highly partisan manner. This is a case in which the outcome depends on the data selected. Broadly speaking, most economists would agree the income growth has increasingly benefited the top 10 percent. Warren’s reasons for that — and her specific numbers — are certainly debatable. But the issue was murky enough that in the end we did not award a rating.
